required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Snacks on Appetite Control
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Controlled, Cross-over Study of the Effect of Snacks on Appetite Control

lead_sponsor.agency: St. Boniface General Hospital Research Centre

clinical_study.source: St. Boniface General Hospital Research Centre

brief_summary.textblock: This clinical trial is being conducted to study whether eating certain snacks will reduce your desire to eat and for a longer period of time compared to other snacks. The investigators are testing 2 different snacks. Study #1 will involve eating 2 different seed-like snacks or water. Study #2 will involve eating pita bread with jam, bread with jam or water. The test snack is higher in protein and/or fibre compared to the reference product.

primary_outcome.measure: total area under the curve for hunger, fullness, desire to eat and prospective consumption visual analog scales
primary_outcome.description: Visual analog scales are administered pre-snack, immediately post-snack and every 30 minutes for 3 hours.

secondary_outcome.measure: number of calories consumed post-snack until bedtime
secondary_outcome.time_frame: time between snack consumption and bedtime

other_outcome.measure: likeability of test and reference products based on sensory scales
other_outcome.time_frame: immediately after eating test or reference product
other_outcome.description: scales will assess overall, appearance, aroma, taste and texture likeability

arm_group.description: gluten-free high protein and high fibre snack
gluten-free snack with similar energy density, but 1/2 the protein as snack #1
gluten-free snack with similar energy density, but less protein and fibre than snack #2

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Body mass index 18-30kg/m2
- males and non-pregnant or non-lactating females
Exclusion Criteria:
- Diagnosis of disease by a medical doctor that requires medical treatment during the study period.
- Daily tobacco use.
- Physical Activity Level >1.8.
- Eat meals at irregular or unusual times.
- Food allergy, aversion or unwillingness to eat study foods.
- Use of any prescription or non-prescription drug, herbal or nutritional supplement known to affect appetite.
- Presence of a gastrointestinal disorder.
- Score >65% on any 1 of the 3 categories of the Three Factor Eating Questionnaire-R18.

facility.name: I. H. Asper Clinical Research Institute

link.description: Obesity in Canada: A joint report from the Public Health Agency of Canada and the Canadian Institute for Health Information
Guidance on the scientific requirements for health claims related to appetite ratings, weight management, and blood glucose concentrations
Draft guidance document: Satiety health claims on food from Health Canada

Appetite control: methodological aspects of the evaluation of foods. Obes Rev. 2010 Mar;11(3):251-70. doi: 10.1111/j.1467-789X.2010.00714.x. Epub 2010 Jan 29. Review.
Paddon-Jones D, Westman E, Mattes RD, Wolfe RR, Astrup A, Westerterp-Plantenga M. Protein, weight management, and satiety. Am J Clin Nutr. 2008 May;87(5):1558S-1561S. Review.
Belski R. Fiber, protein, and lupin-enriched foods: role for improving cardiovascular health. Adv Food Nutr Res. 2012;66:147-215. doi: 10.1016/B978-0-12-394597-6.00004-5. Review.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: St. Boniface General Hospital Research Centre

patient_data.ipd_description: Group results will be emailed or mailed to individuals upon request once they are available.
